cards.back: Application Programming Interface (API) is a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate with each other.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is an application protocol for transmitting hypermedia documents, such as HTML. It is the foundation of data communication on the World Wide Web.
Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is the address used to access a resource on the internet. It consists of a protocol, domain name, and optional path and query parameters.
Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) is the standard markup language for creating web pages and web applications. It defines the structure and content of a webpage.
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is a stylesheet language used for describing the look and formatting of a document written in HTML. It defines the visual style of a webpage.
JavaScript is a high-level, interpreted programming language that enables interactive web pages and web applications. It adds behavior and interactivity to HTML and CSS.
Responsive design is an approach to web design that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes. It ensures optimal user experience across different devices.
Front-end refers to the client-side of a web application. It involves the user interface, user experience, and interactions that users have with the application.
Back-end refers to the server-side of a web application. It involves the logic, database management, and server operations that power the application.
A database is an organized collection of data. It stores and manages data in a structured way, allowing for efficient retrieval, modification, and deletion of data.
A client is a device or software application that requests services or resources from a server. In web development, the client is typically a web browser.
A server is a computer or system that provides resources, services, or functionality to other computers or clients. In web development, the server hosts and serves web applications.
A front-end framework is a collection of pre-written HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code that helps developers build user interfaces more efficiently. Examples include React, Angular, and Vue.
A back-end framework is a collection of pre-written code and libraries that help developers build server-side applications more efficiently. Examples include Express.js, Django, and Ruby on Rails.
Version control is a system that records changes to a file or set of files over time. It allows multiple people to collaborate on a project and track changes made to the codebase.
Git is a distributed version control system that allows multiple developers to collaborate on a project. It tracks changes to files and allows for easy branching and merging of code.
Deployment is the process of making a web application available for use. It involves configuring servers, setting up databases, and ensuring the application is accessible to users.

Testing is the process of evaluating a system or its components to ensure that it meets specified requirements. In web development, testing helps identify and fix bugs and ensure the application works as expected.
Debugging is the process of finding and fixing errors or bugs in a software application. It involves identifying the cause of the problem and making the necessary corrections.
